bayesquad.kernel_gradients module¶

Functions for computing the gradients of Gaussian Process kernels.

bayesquad.kernel_gradients.diagonal_hessian(kernel: GPy.kern.src.kern.Kern, x: numpy.ndarray)[source]¶

Return the hessian of a kernel considered as a function of one variable by constraining both inputs to be equal.

Given a kernel \(K\) and a set of points \(X\), this function will evaluate the hessian of \(K(x, x)\) at each point \(x\) of \(X\).

Parameters:
  • kernel –
    The kernel to be differentiated. Currently supported kernels are:
    • All subclasses of GPy.kern.src.rbf.Stationary
  • x – A 2D array of points, with shape (num_points, num_dimensions).
Returns:

A 3D array of shape (num_points, num_dimensions, num_dimensions).
Return type:

ndarray
bayesquad.kernel_gradients.hessian(kernel: GPy.kern.src.kern.Kern, variable_points: numpy.ndarray, fixed_points: numpy.ndarray)[source]¶

Return the hessian of a kernel evaluated at all pairs from two sets of points.

Given a kernel and two sets \(X, D\) of points (variable_points and fixed_points respectively), this function will evaluate the hessian of the kernel at each pair of points \((x, d)\) with \(x \in X\) and \(d \in D\). The derivatives are taken with respect to the first argument, i.e. \(d\) is regarded as a fixed quantity. Typically, \(D\) will be the set of \(x\) values in the data set of a Gaussian Process, and \(X\) will be the set of \(x\) values at which we wish to find the gradient of the posterior GP.

Parameters:
  • kernel –
    The kernel to be differentiated. Currently supported kernels are:
    • GPy.kern.src.rbf.RBF
  • fixed_points – A 2D array of points, with shape (num_variable_points, num_dimensions).
  • variable_points – A 2D array of points, with shape (num_fixed_points, num_dimensions).
Returns:

A 4D array of shape (num_variable_points, num_fixed_points, num_dimensions, num_dimensions), whose (i, j, k, l)-th element is the (k, l)-th mixed partial derivative of the kernel evaluated at the i-th point of \(X\) and the j-th point of \(D\).
Return type:

ndarray
Raises:

NotImplementedError – If the provided kernel type is not supported. See the parameters list for a list of supported kernels.
bayesquad.kernel_gradients.jacobian(kernel: GPy.kern.src.kern.Kern, variable_points: numpy.ndarray, fixed_points: numpy.ndarray) → numpy.ndarray[source]¶

Return the jacobian of a kernel evaluated at all pairs from two sets of points.

Given a kernel and two sets \(X, D\) of points (variable_points and fixed_points respectively), this function will evaluate the jacobian of the kernel at each pair of points \((x, d)\) with \(x \in X\) and \(d \in D\). The derivative is taken with respect to the first argument, i.e. \(d\) is regarded as a fixed quantity. Typically, \(D\) will be the set of \(x\) values in the data set of a Gaussian Process, and \(X\) will be the set of \(x\) values at which we wish to find the gradient of the posterior GP.

Parameters:
  • kernel –
    The kernel to be differentiated. Currently supported kernels are:
    • GPy.kern.src.rbf.RBF
  • variable_points – A 2D array of points, with shape (num_variable_points, num_dimensions).
  • fixed_points – A 2D array of points, with shape (num_fixed_points, num_dimensions).
Returns:

A 3D array of shape (num_variable_points, num_fixed_points, num_dimensions), whose (i, j, k)-th element is the k-th component of the jacobian of the kernel evaluated at the i-th point of \(X\) and the j-th point of \(D\).
Return type:

ndarray
Raises:

NotImplementedError – If the provided kernel type is not supported. See the parameters list for a list of supported kernels.
